intro: Erysimum cheiranthoides var. japonicum, commonly known as Japanese wallflower, is a flowering plant native to Japan and parts of China. It is a member of the Brassicaceae family, characterized by its showy, bright yellow or orange flowers that bloom in early spring. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm and features simple, lance-shaped leaves with a hairy surface. It thrives in well-drained soil and full sun, making it a popular choice for rock gardens and borders. The flowers attract pollinators such as bees and butterflies, contributing to its ecological value.
